title: Effect of increased salt on onion cells

content.description: A student used a microscope to observe a wet-mount slide of red onion epidermal cells that were suspended in a <math alttext="1 percent" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1%</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="N a C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>NaCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> solution. The student then added a <math alttext="15 percent" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="N a C l" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>NaCl</mtext></mrow></math> solution to the slide and observed the changes that occurred. The student’s observations are represented in Figure 1.
content.question: Figure 1. Student’s observations of onion cells Which of the following most directly explains the changes in the cells?

choices.label: The degradation of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the nuclei of the cells
The lysis of chloroplasts in the cells
The movement of water from the central vacuoles of the cells into the solution
The movement of <math alttext="N a C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from the solution into the cytoplasm of the cells

content.answer: The movement of water from the central vacuoles of the cells into the solution
